I think it's pretty well decided on that the Coen brothers produce movies you either love or hate.  They have their very own style and they continue to stay true to that style; but like anything or anyone, sometimes it works, and sometimes it doesn't.  `Fargo' works, as does `No Country for Old Men'; two films that couldn't be any more different yet are surprisingly very much the same.  My love affair with the Coen's has been spotty to say the least.  I usually tend to adore their more prestigious work, yet I find myself distanced from their more commercial outings (the fact that they actually directed `Intolerable Cruelty' makes me rather sick).

I didn't know what to expect from this movie.  It looked rather funny when I saw the trailers, but the film received such awfully sub par reviews that I was nervous.  Then awards season rolls around and it pops up on the NBR's top ten, and then it starts snagging Globe and BAFTA nominations and I'm scratching my head thinking `this wasn't supposed to be that good'.

I finally saw it.

It wasn't that good.

Okay, here's the problem; it's not `that' funny.  Here's another problem; it's not `that' intelligent.  Everyone prides the Coen's on their clever mix of humor and brains, making very adult, very mature and very intelligent comedies.  This one isn't really funny or smart.

The film tells a convoluted (but it's not as `twisty, turny' as it thinks it is) tale of CIA analyst Osbourne Cox who has recently been fired.  Under emotional stress he decides to take time to write his memoirs.  Meanwhile his wife Katie is having an affair with Harry Pfarrer, a federal marshal married to a children's author.  Urged by her lawyer to get a copy of her husband's financials before pursuing divorce, Katie accidentally copies his memoirs and when they wind up laying around on a gym changing room floor two airheads think they've stumbled onto some secret CIA `stuff'.  Attempting to blackmail Cox into paying over some much needed cash, these two nitwits wind up getting mixed in some serious `stuff'.

The film is very easy to follow, despite all the characters and plot twists.  Like I said, they're not as convoluted as they think they are being.  As far as the acting is concerned, it is really sporadic.  Some of it is great, some of it is bland and some of it is horrendous.

Brad Pitt is comedic genius here, playing the densest character in the bunch.  This allows him to just create a purely comedic character, with no baggage or additional strings to pull.  He's just funny, and he should have had a lot more screen time.  Richard Jenkins is also very endearing and stands out amongst the rest of the cast, mainly because he's the only character who isn't an idiot.

That's another problem with this movie.  There is really not one intelligent person in the entire film.  Everyone you meet is dumber than the last person you met, so they all wind up being just as ridiculous as the last.  A few morons sifted into a comedy can help pepper in the fun a bit, but when there is not one person who seems remotely intelligent it can make for a rather uninteresting time.

George Clooney is very over the top, as is John Malkovich, but Malcovich handles his characters emotional deterioration much better than Clooney.  Clooney just comes off like a moron; Malcovich elevates his characters moronic status, if that makes any sense.  Frances McDormand and Tilda Swinton have both received nominations for their performances but I fail to see why.  I somewhat can see the Swinton love a bit, for she is rather good with what she is given (which isn't much mind you), but McDormand is in my opinion `worst in show'.  I just didn't get what she was doing.  I love her, don't get me wrong.  She is usually one of my favorite actresses, but she just was not funny here, and she was obviously trying very hard to be.

In the end I just cannot get behind this one.  It has its moments (every one with Pitt is really hilarious) but as a whole it just doesn't work as well as it should have.  I'd give it a C, but Pitt is a remarkable A+.

"Burn After Reading" suggests this is a spy caper and it is in a strange way.  The movie starts when the long-time CIA analyst Osborn Cox (John Malkovich) is fired without good reason and he starts work on a "tell all book" of the CIA.  The CIA Analyst's spouse downloads information from Osborn's computer to prepare for divorce.  She thinks it is mainly financial information and does not want to be cheated out of her share.  Somehow the CD ends up at the Hard Body Gym, where Frances McDormand (Linda Litzke), a love-starved aging employee, and Brad Pitt (Chad Feldheimer) a personal trainer, who is a good friend find it and see there may be a way to use it for money through blackmailing Osborn Cox.

Linda's search for love continues with on-line dating "meet-ups"  and her constant calls to the insurance company to complain that the four procedures she needs are not elective - they are important to her life and career.  The procedures should be paid for.  They aren't.  George Clooney (Harry Pfarrer) is one of her "dates" - but he also married and is carrying on an affair with Osborn's wife.  He is a "cheater".  As an aside - it shows him building a sex machine with Home Depot materials.  When completed, Linda is given a demo of sorts.  So many boring lives and such a need for excitement is one of many sub-plots.

There are many dire consequences from the Blackmail attempt, as well as visits by Linda and Chad to the Russian Embassy to try and sell the CD for money.  The Russians seem skeptical.

The CIA is following as their "mole" in the Russian Embassy alerts them of the attempt to sell information - but they are puzzled about the whole reason for doing it?

The movie kept my attention, trying to make sense of many twists and turns.  Brad as Chad was the most clear character in the film.

I sure was excited to see Burn After Reading.  I consider Raising Arizona, The Big Lebowski, and Fargo as some of my favorite movies.  But boy were those hopes dashed in a heartbeat when I actually viewed this one.  This doesn't even come close to quality of those movies.

Burn After Reading has a whole array of problems, but here is a list of what comes to mind.  First and foremost, everyone tries WAY too hard to be funny and quirky.  Whenever you notice each and every character doing a "look at me, look at me" against every other character, that's not a good sign.  Plus, there isn't a single likeable character.  There's no one you can "root for."  Even the one character you thought you could root for, ends up being just as horrible as the rest of them.  They're just all horrible people and you don't want any of them to succeed in any way.  Also, Brad Pitt and Frances McDormand are just WAY too stupid for words.  I know they're supposed to be, but this is just annoyingly so.  It's not really funny, just annoying.

The only reason I'm even giving this two stars instead of one, is simply because of a few scenes.  There are a few standout scenes that float to the top and are actually pretty funny.  I don't want to ruin it, if you're actually going to watch this, but a few are good.  Plus, anytime JK Simmons is on screen, you realize how fantastic that guy really is.  Pity he's only in it for about 5 minutes total.  He also makes you realize just how much the other actors are waaaaaaaay overacting and mugging for the camera.

Overall, as a Coen brothers fan, I was sorely disappointed.  Go re-rent Raising Arizona, Big Lebowski or Fargo again instead.  You'll be doing yourself a favor.

Burn After Reading is another Cohen brothers film. After last year's award winning No Country for Old Men (which I haven't seen), they return to comedy with a spy thriller that features, instead of covert CIA agents and national secrets, a bunch of buffoons.

The first thing you'll notice before you get into the purpose and intent of the film is the music and filming techniques. It is straight spy thriller stuff. Suspensful music, framing shots you'd expect in a Bourne or Bond film. Then you begin to realize that all the characters are morons. The great cast begins with John Malkovic as Oswald Cox, a midlevel CIA agent who quits his job instead of accepting a reassignment. He decides to write his memoirs. Those memoirs end up in the hands of two Hardbodies gym employees Linda Litzke and Chad Feldheimer (Frances McDormand and Brad Pitt). They think they are in possession of some top secret information, and they will do anything to turn the "top secret" info into money.

George Clooney plays Harry Pfarrer, a treasury department official who thinks he has his wife fooled that he is a good husband. While his wife is away, he is sleeping with Katie Cox (Tilda Swinton), Oswald's wife. He also is on an internet dating service and mees Linda Litzke. The movie ends with all the characters and story lines interacting in a crazy way.

This movie really has no plot, in that there is no final objective. The movie instead has fun with the spy thriller genre and explores what would happen if the dumbest people in the world thought the were dealing with some top secret information.

This movie isn't for everyone. There is a lot of foul language and a few scenes of gruesome violence. But that is expected in a "R" movie. All the great actors in the film play against their normal on-screen personal. They aren't sexy or smart or smooth. They are just dumb. You can judge how well you like your movie by your reaction to what happens to Chad Feldheimer (Pitt) when he is hiding in a closet. I laughed. Overall, I enjoyed this Cohen brothers film.

It is rather surprising at the number of reviewers who detest "Burn After Reading," an obviously sizzlin' satire. What do they expect from the Coen Brothers? Why, this film could even be called a madcap comedy with a criminal twist.

"Burn After Reading" has been "read" a number of ways: a spoof of the intelligence community (my call on the funniest part of the film), a social commentary on extra-marital and internet affairs, and a poke at mid-life crises. Let me add one more dimension to this adept Coen Brothers film of masterful ensemble acting: the apparent inability for one human to really know another, resulting in superficial intimacies.

People are who they are. Even if they switch their partners, they still are who they are. Case in point: Tilda Swindon plays a cold, haughty type with John Malkovich, but once she and George Clooney actually shack up, they become who they are once again and disenchanted with each other.

Clooney enjoys sex with Francis McDormand's character until he learns she is part of his paranoid misadventure. She is willing to sell trade secrets to the Russian Embassy to make enough money for plastic surgery. Her employer at the health club is obviously in love with her and is willing to overlook her suddenly bad work habits. Brad Pitt perfectly plays an airhead personal trainer, yet is fearless in espionage matters. John Malkovich is fired from Intelligence and writes his memoirs in a drunken stupor to get back at the agency. In fact, it is Malkovich's papers that get into the hands of Francis! It is a big loop-di-loop. Even though I gave important parts of the story above, none is a spoiler!

Even Clooney's wife, a children's book author for pete's sake, is having an affair. Do we really know another human being, even those we love and live with? The Coens say no. All these people are solid citizens, yet behave abominably when their little universes fall apart.

One reviewer describes Francis McDormand as the third Coen Brother. Considering that Francis gets what she wants at the end, his statement is verified and justified! But consider again, does she really win?

Then we watched the commentary, and one of the principals made the remark that it was a "comedy about old people", and it was a Eureka moment for me. Most of these characters are in some ways privileged, but they just don't enjoy it, or have sense enough to realize the problem is within themselves, yet they are obsessed at finding that "magical" answer. It doesn't hurt that the Coen display a feel for the Beltway life of Washington that they did for the deep South in O Brother, or for L. A. in Liebowski. How do guys from New York understand places that are so "distant from New York"?

These are a bunch of middle-aged plus people (except for Brad Pitt, who's character is none too bright), who all think they are smarter than they really are, and who all believe that somehow life (or some person or combination of persons) is conspiring to deprive them of some deeper part of the pie that will guarantee their fulfillment.

If you are a Boomer, who has ever had a job where you didn't feel there was anywhere for you to progress, or who has ever been in a dead-ending relationship, I think you will see the brilliant humor in this movie. For you younger people, it will probably happen to you too in time.

This movie to me is very perceptive about how easy it is to get things all wrong about what your problems are -- especially as you are playing the "back 9" of your career and your life. In fact, there's quite an object lesson here with which the Bard of Avon and his Polonius would be quite at home -- if you are honest with yourself, you are not likely to be dishonest with anyone else or be taken advantage of. If you can't be honest with yourself, you are quite at risk to do bizarre and mistaken things.

Legitimately, several of the scenes and elements of the plot do echo "The Big Lebowski", so I recommend you give yourself a chance to watch this movie a couple of times -- it grew on me, as did Lebowski or O Brother. The cast is marvelous, and the Coen brothers get everything the movie needs out of these fine actors.

Did you ever wonder what Fargo would look like had Frances McDormand and William Macy switched roles? In Burn After Reading, McDormand summons her inner Jerry Lundegaard as Linda, a fitness club worker looking for love via Internet dating. Convinced she needs plastic surgery, Linda sets in motion a scheme to raise the money. The results are comical: people are fired, divorced and some are even murdered. The twists will elicit gasps and giggles. Not unlike other films by Joel and Ethan Coen, we find other characters on parallel tracks: Katie (Tilda Swinton) is cheating on her husband, CIA analyst Osborne Cox (John Malkovich), with federal marshal Harry (George Clooney), who instead finds Linda. I'd be remiss to leave out Linda's co-worker, Chad (Brad Pitt), a fitness trainer whose espionage training perhaps comes entirely from watching Mission Impossible reruns. Critics will likely point to The Big Lebowski and Fargo perhaps expecting fans will make comparisons and toss out Burn After Reading. Instead, fans of the Coen Brothers will lovingly seat this crime tale as they would an odd relative at the Thanksgiving table. There's plenty of room for everyone. I give Burn After Reading four stars, although I suspect this movie, like The Big Lebowski and Fargo, will grow on me even more with time.

PLOT
Low-lives try their luck extorting CIA operatives.

REVIEW
The Coen Brothers' hit-or-miss filmography, which with gems such as "Fargo" (1996) and "No Country for Old Men" (2007), has more recently erred on the side of hit, makes an incredible miss with "Burn After Reading". The film's nothing more than a mish-mash of unremarkable sequences.

By about midway through the film, you know it's not going to amount to anything much. One of the characters reveals a strange home invention that is either meant to shock the audience into laughter, or reveal something odd about the character, because as yet he has no depth. It's like when it starts raining toads in "Magnolia" (1999). When the home invention scene fails, the Coens try for shock value with a repulsive scene in which John Malkovitch hacks to death poor Richard Jenkins.

What is particularly annoying is that the performances of Malkovitch, Frances McDormand, Brad Pitt and J K Simmons are simply amalgamations of characters they each played in earlier films.  Further, if you have seen the film, imagine if Tilda Swinton's character were removed completely - would this be consequential?

"Burn After Reading" has been touted as a quirky comedy/thriller. It's a tiny bit quirky. It's funny once or twice. It's hardly thrilling.

The Coen brothers make an interesting team.  They have a catalogue of superior movies, along with a few lesser ones.  They seem to be unable to top the unique comic absurdity of Lebowski, although O Brother was a close second.  Hudsucker was a pretty good absurd comedy and Barton Fink was a workable blend of comedy and drama.

Similarly, their more serious features like Fargo and No Country for Old Men (based on a book they didn't write) were very well cast and well made.

Burn After Reading was short, bland, and relied too much on star power instead of any interesting sort of satire or a steady stream of comic lines.  They even resort to an adult form of prop comedy which is not as titillating or amusing as they thought it would be.

This film, according to my experience with it and according to the Coens' comments in the bonus features, seems more like a film school project without much of a point.  They weren't all that passionate about satirizing spy movies like Borne Identity or Breach or the scores of others.  To me, this film is a gathering of some talented actors performing well beneath their standards.

It is funny in some parts, but the spoof factor is not very insightful and is far from hilarious.  I expect more from the Coen Brothers.  This is more on the level of Intolerable Cruelty or Ladykillers, neither of which represents their A-game.

Might be worth a rental if you adore everything the Coens do, but I wouldn't buy it.

The Coen Brothers are in familiar territory with "Burn After Reading", a black comedy revolving around a hare-brained extortion scheme. Osbourne Cox (John Malkovich) has quit his analyst job at the CIA rather than be demoted on account of his drinking problem. His frosty bourgeois wife Katie (Tilda Swinton), a pediatrician who couldn't be less suited to the job, considers the loss of income good reason for divorce. Linda Litzke (Frances McDormand) is a bubble-headed gym employee in desperate want of four expensive cosmetic surgeries. When a CD containing Osbourne's memoir-in progress is found in the gym's locker room, Linda's buff, vapid co-worker Chad Feldheimer (Brad Pitt) deduces that it is top secret stuff. Linda sees an opportunity to get her surgeries and impress her new lover Harry Pfarrer (George Clooney), who makes a hobby of meeting women through an internet dating service, in spite of having a wife and a mistress, Katie.

This overcomplicated plot is in contrast to Joel and Ethan Coen's last film, "No Country for Old Men", whose structure was a simple chase. Everyone is connected to everyone else and to that blasted CD without knowing it. The deadpan incredulity of two CIA bureaucrats who are trying to sort it all out produces some of the film's best lines. There has been criticism that Linda and Chad are too stupid to be interesting or sympathetic, but all characters involved in the cockamamie schemes that are the basis of most thrillers are, in fact, stupid, and the brothers Coen are making fun of that here. Brad Pitt's cheerful dim-bulb Chad is one of his most memorable performances. And though we're immersed in dumbness, minor characters and well-placed set decoration fill the film out with more subtle comedy. As to whether "Burn After Reading" makes a political statement, well, the CIA sweeps the carnage under the carpet without trying very hard to understand what's going on. Under those circumstances, we might all do the same. But I wonder if the Coens did not mean something by it.

"Burn After Reading"  is the recent Cohn Brothers drama about a pair of not-too-bright gym employees (Brad Pitt, Frances McDormand) who discover what they think is classified CIA information on a disc left in a locker and try to demand a ransom for its return.  Because they're not very good at blackmail, however, their plan soon spins way out of control.  Costarring George Clooney, Tilda Swinton, John Malkovich, and Richard Jenkins, "Burn After Reading" is one of the quirkiest movies from the Cohns, who put "quirky" on the cinematic map.  The revelation here is Brad Pitt, who plays his character, Chad Feldheimer, as an enthusiastic dimwit who never realizes he's way out of his depth.  Watching him plot with coworker Linda Litzke (McDormand), who joins in the blackmail scheme because she needs a lot of cash for a series of cosmetic surgeries, is a joy.  The movie is very funny, but does take a couple of unexpected detours to the dark side, so be warned.  The DVD contains a making-of featurette and a comic piece featuring George Clooney as he returns for his third collaboration with Joel and Ethan Cohn.

Many of the Amazon reviewers of "Burn After Reading" fail to understand, or they resent, if only dimly understood, the point of all Coen Brothers films: to provide an entertainment in which the audience can feel comfortably superior to characters that are in over their heads. All the stylistic and character aspects that many reviewers construe as flaws are in fact the entire point of watching a Coen Brothers film. Where else, other than as a Amazon film reviewer, can one feel so smugly superior and amused at the strivings and shortcomings of others, while celebrating the satisfaction of the bully, with the balm of comedy and farce, than in a Coen Brothers film? Not all of us can be paid to feel that way, some of us have to pay others, like the Coens, to provide us with two hours or so of escape to these wonderful sentiments. "Burn After Reading" is in fact yet another deliciously perceptive jab at the American reverence for and addiction to optimism, excessive self-esteem and non-judgemental behavior. The reason a lot of reviewers don't like this film is because the characters are probably a little too close to home for comfort.

Consequently, the pacing is tedious and the overall effect sluggish and disjointed.

My wife and I were drawn to the film by the cast and sat down to watch it eagerly, but, half way through, we were forcing ourselves to sit through  it.

Though not as manic as "Raising Arizona", and less subtle than "Fargo", the Coens have once again presented the "human condition" with comedic style and aplomb. They've never missed in their casting choices, and once again we have a bunch of clueless crazies. Indeed, Brad Pitt took Johnny Suede to new heights and beyond. The always reliable Frances McDormand looks as if nothing could be more fun, and Clooney and Malkovich are so very intense, creating outrageously lovable idiots. Tilda Swinton is the only grounded character, with that glint of satiric bitchiness that is most enjoyable. Richard Jenkins is also grounded, though baffled by the insanity. I can't blab away the plot, as others did, but suffice it to say that this is a story about bad decisions taken way beyond comprehension. It's no end of fun, and if you pay attention, you'll be breathless when it's over. Terrific film, and another feather in the enigmatic hat of the Coen brothers. They cannot be labelled, out-guessed or pinned down in any genre; they succeed in all: "Miller's Crossing", "O Brother...", "No Country...",  and, especially, their first, "Blood Simple". (I still don't know what the hell was going on in "Barton Fink"). The Coens are eclectic in their choices, and isn't that refreshing!? Unfortunately, there weren't enough DVD extras for me. It was apparent, though, that all involved were thrilled to be a part of it.

Where else, other than as a Amazon film reviewer, can one feel so smugly superior and amused at the strivings and shortcomings of others, while celebrating the satisfaction of the bully, with the balm of comedy and farce, than in a Coen Brothers film? Not all of us can be paid to feel that way, some of us have to pay others, like the Coens, to provide us with two hours or so of escape to these wonderful sentiments. "Burn After Reading" is in fact yet another deliciously perceptive jab at the American reverence for and addiction to optimism, excessive self-esteem and non-judgemental behavior. The reason a lot of reviewers don't like this film is because the characters are probably a little too close to home for comfort.

When the CIA spy Osborne Cox (John Malkovich) got fired for alcoholism, he lost more than his job. He also lost a CD with sensitive information that fell into the hands of Chad (Brad Pitt), a gum-smacking, fist-pumping fitness trainer at Hardbodies, and his colleague Linda Litzke, who's a serial internet dater with dreams of extensive cosmetic surgery. This dimwitted duo concocts a plan to sell Osborne's CD to the Russians to pay for Linda's surgery. Cox is also losing his wife, Katie, who is having an affair with Harry (George Clooney), a federal marshal who's a sex addict. Unintended consequences are the result for everyone in this clever comedy from director-writers Ethan and Joel Coen (No Country for Old Men). It was refreshing to see Pitt and Clooney cast in roles far outside their types, and to watch the Coens satire politics, sex, body image, addictions, and the longing for love.

After the astounding "No Country for Old Men," "Burn After Reading" is easy to dismiss as light-hearted.  It concerns a burnt-out CIA operative (John Malkovich) and his hen-pecking wife (Tilda Swinton) who's cheating with a serial adulterer (George Clooney).  Tossed into the middle are two health club employees (Frances McDormand and Brad Pitt) looking to make a few bucks on the side.

Malkovich is a scene-stealer as always; if you want to see something absolutely terrifying, picture a drunk, raging Malkovich wielding a hatchet.  McDormand is terrific as always; Swinton plays up her "Michael Clayton" role, taking it up a notch a few levels.  Clooney gets by on charm alone for the first half, which is really all that's required; afterwards, he holds his own with the rest of the gang.  And Pitt...well, it's nice to see such a reknowned actor breaking image and playing a complete schmutz.  He's not exactly in "The Assassination of Jesse James" form, but he's perfect for the role.  Supporting credit goes to the wonderful Richard Jenkins and the hilarous J. K. Simmons.

As stated before: It's easy to pass this film off as light-hearted, when compared to the Coen Brothers' previous picture.  But that would be to ignore the Brothers' entire catalogue. The final scene in "Burn After Reading," though absolutely hilarious, is easily as dark and thought-provoking as anything "No Country For Old Men" had to offer.  This may be an inferior film on the whole, but it's still a damn-fine ensemble comedy, a dark and thoughtful piece that rockets along thanks to stellar writing, superb direction, and top-notch acting.  It may not be another "Fargo" or "No Country For Old Men," but "Burn After Reading" more than deserves its place in the Coen Brothers' catalogue.

First off, if you've already seen this in theaters, consider seeing the  DVD, if only for the Bonus features, where the Coen Brothers and the cast of Burn After Reading show glimpses into how the Coen process works.

In Burn After Reading, they tie together such diverse subjects as liposuction,spies and gym instructors. Frances McDormand, who is a favorite of the Coens, once again shines in this movie. She is a favorite of mine and I have to watch closely to see the art behind her work. She is simply believable to me in nearly every role.

George Clooney and Brad Pitt both get to be awkward and clownish. Pitt plays a gym instructor who discovers a disc created by Osborne Cox (played by John Malkovich) Cox is not having a good year, having been demoted as a spy and also about to have his marriage implode.

When Pitt and McDormand (both gym instructors) discover the tape, it sets into motion a whole sequences of plot twists and turns that kept me hooked. I foresaw some of them but was surprised by many other scenes....and some moments were simply laugh out loud funny. Others were horrifying. Mostly, it was a very weird movie, in the best sense of the word "weird".

I also felt that there was something poignant about this film. In the ending scene, when there is musing about what happened and the lessons learned, I felt the Coens were coming as close to delivering an overall message - or warning - as they ever do, perhaps hinting at the dangers about being too complacent about security and safety and depending on the government to provide that. The movie left me wanting more, so I went back and looked at key scenes again.

First off, reviewing a popular movie negatively is never a popular choice. Disagree with me all you like; reviews are opinion based, and this is my opinion. That's all it is. If you loved the movie, don't take my review personally.

The Coen brothers usually make a fantastic movie. "Raising Arizona", "Fargo", and "No Country for Old Men" are all five star films in my book. Even their lesser known movies are great, with the exception of the boring "Lady Killers". Coming on the heels of "No County for Old Men", my expectation level for "Burn After Reading" was high. Not unfairly high; I didn't expect another award winner, jut an entertaining movie with a quality story and descent acting. What I got was a fairly pointless melodramatic movie with characters it was hard to empathize with, like, or want to see succeed.

No, this is not an awful movie that is impossible to watch (well maybe during Clooney's ridiculously camera-aware mugging near the end of the film) but it isn't up to the Coen's usual standards either. All the elements of a good movie are there: quality name actors, a plot that is a highly sarcastic take on a pumped-up spy thriller, and the Coen's typical evocative camera work. What's missing is that cohesiveness that makes a movie not just a collection of good ingredients, but a finished product.

This is a movie about stupid people doing stupid things. There is no real plot; the characters careen about in their self-absorbed turbidity, digging themselves deeper and deeper into trouble. Each character seems totally incapable of self examination. The characters do not grow or change at all during the entire film. Black comedy is something the Coens are usually adept at. Unfortunately, in this film they seem more concerned with shock value and impressing the viewer with their sly wit. It feels like they are snickering with glee over their own intelligence at having imagined such sad, stupid, and shallow characters.

Every character in the film is remarkably unlikable with the possible exception of John Malkovich's recently fired, drunken, former CIA employee crotchetiness. Clooney, who I usually think does a fantastic job, (see "Syriana" or "Michael Clayton") is almost unbearable he's so self absorbed and aware of the camera. He even appears to be mugging at times. Pitt's character is funny, but doesn't stick around long enough to be more than a footnote. The acting isn't bad overall, it just that the characters are so miserable that it's hard to appreciate it.

This is a movie you can definitely watch just once. I know I'll likely get lit up for giving a relatively popular movie a negative review, but honestly, if Fargo is a 5, and No Country for Old Men is a 5, how can you put this movie in the same league as those films? Even 4 stars seems excessive for a movie as light as this one. I can't argue with 3 stars if you really liked the movie, but the reality is that I didn't like it at all and never will. Rent this one if you have to see it, but don't waste your money buying it.

The theme of this film is that people are stupid, from the leaders of the so-called "intelligence community" to the people who toil in the health spa business.  Unfortunately the plot is a little fuzzy in getting this across at times.

For about the first third of the movie, the viewer cannot get a handle on what he is seeing.  We see an "intelligence agent" get fired, go home, try to tell his distracted wife.  Soon we see a health spa clerk talking to a plastic surgeon about several surgical procedures she wants to have.  Various other characters appear, seeming to have little or no connection to what is happening.

Then finally, if the viewer is extremely patient, connections are made.
Everything turns around the health spa clerk trying to get the money to reinvent herself, as she says, and a misplaced CD that contains the start of the spy's memoirs and financial records that his wife has downloaded for her divorce attorney.

Confused?  So is the story up to a point.  There are no competent human beings portrayed in this little opus, and in that respect it is like the Coen brothers' masterpkiece, "Fargo."  In the end it is like that scene from a Marx Brothers film, in which a dozen people tumble out of a tiny shipboard cabin.  Only one character, perhaps the dumbest one, is anywhere near successful.

It's OK, I suppose, to distract for a couple of hours, but it is no great shakes as art.

Short Attention Span Summary (SASS):

1. CIA analyst Cox (John Malkovich) has a falling out with the agency, and decides to write a tell-all memoir.
2. His wife (Tilda Swinton) wants a divorce, and to make sure she's forearmed with his finances, she burns a copy of some of his computer files
3. Said files fall into the incapable hands of clueless gym employees Chad (Brad Pitt) and Linda (Frances McDormand), who decide to try extortion as a fund raising exercise.
4. No prizes for guessing that it doesn't quite work as planned
5. Meanwhile, Mrs. Cox is having an affair, Linda is looking for both love and cosmetic surgery, and Treasury agent Harry (George Clooney) is sleeping around.
6. Black comedy of errors follows with some rather unpredictable twists.

Fans of black comedy will thoroughly enjoy this movie, which is well directed, brilliantly acted and immensely entertaining.  Kudos go to Malkovich, Pitt, Swinton and Clooney, but the top award definitely goes to McDormand, who will have you sharing her pain.

Four and a half stars go to the Coen Brothers for this bleak look at life, adultery, blackmail and people behaving badly.

Amanda Richards
